The value in wealth creation is therefore immense. Export earning and its importance to the local economies is vital. So I take more than a passing interest in these horticultural bills and others like it that come before the parliament.

If we look at the total value of major horticultural products across the nation, we are looking at an industry worth in excess of $3 billion. What is important is the potential for growth; that is where the emphasis should be. The emphasis should not be on what growth is but on what it can be. Honourable members need only examine the exciting projections for the wine industry, for example, to recognise that enormous potential. The wine industry proposes to triple its export earnings by the turn of the century. This will require an increased planting of vineyards of some 30,000 hectares which will probably be almost entirely contained in the electorates of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) and the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer). It is a prime wine grape growing area in Australia which enjoys a good climate and the availability of a secure water resource and produces a quality product that honourable members of the House often enjoy.

None of this is new and it has not suddenly emerged. Just to put horticulture into perspective, Australia enjoys 21 per cent of world banana production. For oranges the figure is 11 per cent and for honey 24 per cent. These compare with figures for our bigger broadacre primary industries of 38 per cent for wool, from grazing, and 17 per cent for wheat. So the potential is there for enormous wealth creation for the nation.

I might just dwell on two major products produced in my electorate, citrus and dried vine fruit. These are valuable commodities worth at least $200 million per annum, just in my electorate, and they are being squeezed from both ends with unrelenting pressure. They are being squeezed from the market end because of the difficulty with the commodity price squeeze and from the production end because of cost pushes, which is the point that the member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) has made to the government. That is where this government can have some influence.

If you squeeze an orange too hard from both ends, it bursts. Sadly, far too many of my horticultural constituents have gone bust or are about to do so. It is flippant for the member for Leichhardt to dismiss the problem by looking at national production figures and ignoring the very real difficulties of people that are involved in intensive horticulture, often in smallholdings. We know that, in terms of advantages of size, that is something that cannot continue, but these are real people caught in that commodity squeeze and cost squeeze.

The government can choose to hide from its responsibility by claiming little influence over world commodity prices. However, as I have said, it has direct control over cost inputs and I think it is time for it to accept that responsibility. That is what previous coalition speakers have said, and no doubt following speakers from our side will continue to make that point.

Fancy the government forcing a massive hike in fuel prices by forced excise increases, if it purports to be concerned about horticulture. Despite the request from the member for Gwydir, nobody from the other side has yet attempted to defend those budget decisions. Fancy imposing a superannuation guarantee charge on itinerant labour, from which the only beneficiaries have been fund managers and insurance companies. It shows a lack of recognition of the particular seasonal labour requirements in horticulture. Fancy having a dog in a manger attitude to every form of taxation depreciation proposal put forward by those industries, whose only intention is a desperate bid to survive, seeking any small fillip to encourage them.

Fancy abolishing tariff control on imported citrus and dried fruit without assisting those industries to adjust. The revenue for citrus is now as low as $40 per tonne for juicing product when the cost of production is of the order of $150 a tonne. I have a complete file of growers' payment remittance advices that have been sent to me as examples of the problem they face. One particular grower sent me his payment remittance advice which was in fact in the negative. For 26.3 tonnes of product for juicing, he received a bill for $183. That is a situation that is completely untenable for an industry that has accepted the challenge of the new free international trade ideology and has accepted the challenge of removing the fortress structures of the past but is simply seeking some level of assistance to adjust. I hold the view that Australia has paid an enormous price by steadfastly reducing its barriers, and that this has been disproportionately paid by particularly the citrus growers and dried fruit growers in my electorate.

The problem with horticulture is that when one is faced with a pack-out of citrus, where one attempts to produce a premium fresh product for exporting and the domestic market, the pack-out is only of the order of 60 per cent. In other words, only 40 per cent of what is produced can be packed for a fresh market. The remaining 60 per cent goes to the juice industry. This is because the industry has not kept pace with sufficient new varieties and needs to replant. That is why this legislation supporting the broadening of the base of levy collections for research and development is a very important step in advising growers on new varieties.

Simply ripping out trees or vines and planting new ones does not ensure one's income, and often it takes from five to seven years before a first crop can be produced. This is a real difficulty for horticulture, which is faced with the need to be more efficient, to use varieties which are more amenable to mechanical harvesting, and to produce a much better fresh fruit product. I do not think this government has recognised that. It does not seem to have recognised the need for restructure in an industry that it has forced onto a purportedly level playing field in free world trade.

Sadly, the end result of this has shattered the confidence of many of my growers and forced far too many of them onto some form of government handout to survive. To make matters worse, the confidence of the financial market has been substantially eroded, so that those who are keen to install state-of-the-art irrigation or new trellising to take advantage of new technology, particularly in viticulture, are denied access to capital because of the lack of confidence in the financing industry.

Whilst I commend the government for bringing this legislation forward, I want to warn that growers, particularly citrus growers, are hard-pressed to have any money to pay levies at all, but I have the confidence that they will continue to do that as they have for some substantial time.

So what can be done to assist horticulture? Let us make a genuine bipartisan contribution to assist horticulture, which has the potential to emerge as an important export earner for this nation. Most forms of horticultural production in Australia have a high labour intensity, much higher than in broadacre agriculture. By way of example, as a proportion of farm costs, labour costs on average in the wine grape industry are 56 per cent, in citrus 47 per cent, and in canning fruit 51 per cent; as against broadacre primary commodities like wheat at 22 per cent and wool at 25 per cent. Unfortunately, in Australia the cost of our labour is inordinately high. Efforts are being made to reduce the dependency on labour, but it must be remembered that it will always be a high labour industry.

I want to add to the member for Gwydir's comments about the attitude adopted with respect to the taxation treatment of capital expenditure. Access to capital is one problem, but the taxation treatment of expenditure on new horticultural plantations still remains a vital issue.

The current treatment of expenditure for the establishment of horticultural plantations distorts investment decisions by growers and disadvantages horticulture, which is based on a perennial crop, as against annual crops. Depreciation is allowed for plant and equipment, but trees are not regarded as such. Costs associated with establishment are deemed to be of a capital nature and as such are not tax deductible.

A significant number of stone fruit growers in the Woorinen and Tresco areas of my electorate have adopted state-of-the-art technology in respect of the varieties they plant and state-of-the-art grading with computer aided facilities. They are very well advanced in their attitude towards their future. However, some of the varieties they are planting only survive three or four years. Because of the idiosyncrasies of the market, a new variety is then sought and so the growers are required to plant a new variety within a short space of time. So the approach of regarding the tree as a capital item is not going to continue, because within a few years it could be removed and a new variety replace it.

As the honourable member for Gwydir has, I urge the government to give the matter much fairer consideration. I ask it to remove the current anomalies, which are recognised by the Industry Commission and, to some extent, were recognised by the government in the last deal it made with the wine industry. Because of the need to get the wine tax increases through the House urgently, the government made some moves towards addressing this problem.

Let me compare the tax treatment of fruit producers with some of our competitor nations. For example, in the United States of America, fruit producers are allowed a 10 per cent depreciation, on a straight line basis, for trees and vines. Indeed, 10 per cent depreciation is also permitted in New Zealand, although it is on a diminishing value formula. So the different tax treatments in our competing countries are reducing the international competitiveness of horticulture.

The coalition often addresses the issue of transport costs. Transport is a major factor in the cost of production and supply of horticultural products, both domestically and internationally. Most horticultural products are moved in Australia by road, and all levels of government need to press on with the reforming of Australia's domestic shipping, rail and air transport.

The difficulty is that relatively small volumes are involved and that reduces the access to bulk carriers that are available for the wheat industry and the oil and gas industries. Apart from dried vine fruit, it is very difficult to fill a ship entirely with one of the horticultural commodities. As well, these commodities are of a sensitive nature and it is necessary to get them to the market as quickly as possible to take advantage of the small window of opportunity that the honourable member for Gwydir has referred to.

Finally, I refer to the issue brought to the attention of this chamber by the honourable member for Gwydir regarding the citrus industry's urgent need to have other than concentrate fruit juices exempt from sales tax. It has already been stated that as of 1 January 1995 the previous concession for 25 per cent local content is going to be removed, and, in a disgruntled way, the industry has accepted that. It has realised the reality of the GATT requirements and Australia's urgent need to convince the world that it is prepared to do the right thing. But it seems to me that there is an enormous anomaly in imposing sales tax on fresh orange juice.

We could adopt a GATT friendly procedure that would not preclude any country in the world from exporting fresh juice to this country. They will have a lot more difficulty in achieving that, of course. But there is an anomaly when whole milk and tea and coffee and whole fresh oranges do not incur a tax but orange juice does. The citrus industry will gain the capacity for further growth in the important `not from concentrate'—fresh—segment of the orange juice market. The industry, through its own initiative, has taken a determined direction to overcome the pressures it is facing with cost push and commodity difficulties.

I think the government ought to look seriously at this issue. It has been considering it for a reasonable time and my citrus growers are waiting anxiously for a decision. A sales tax exemption for 100 per cent `not from concentrate' fruit juices is an opportunity for the government to remove the local content rule without crippling the industry. As I have said, the citrus industry has suffered enough. It is an opportunity for the government to avoid even further damages to fragile regional economies and it will give an unbelievable fillip to an industry that is flagging in its confidence. I think that the adjustment can certainly be made in a revenue neutral way. I would urge government representatives who are still present in this chamber to urge the minister to support this initiative and give my citrus growers the badly needed fillip that they are waiting for.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1994, the Horticultural Export Charge Amendment Bill 1994 and the Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill 1994. In doing so, I address my remarks basically to the horticultural industry and mainly to the area of exports and export performance. Australia's export performance in recent years has grown in certain areas, but growth overall has been small compared with our Southern Hemisphere competitors. A gradual reduction of tariffs on many horticultural products, and the requirement that quarantine barriers to further domestic access are satisfied, means that our domestic producers will face increasing competition from horticultural imports. It is a fact of life.

PARA.TAB: Current planning trends and forecast production increases, both in Australia and overseas, indicate that Australian horticultural industries will need to concentrate on developing and maintaining export markets. There is also scope for regaining domestic market share and developing competitive import replacement industries, particularly processed products.

Enhanced export efforts will only be successful if the fragmented nature of the industry is re-shaped into a modern, dynamic, international industry. The opportunities developing, especially in the Asia-Pacific region, will only be available for a relatively short period before the distribution systems are taken up by other countries.

Australian exports of fresh and processed horticultural products are likely to increase three-fold in value to approximately $2 billion by the year 2000. An important development in the trade will be the role played by large, well financed, vertically integrated businesses exporting on a significant scale. The major destination for Australian horticultural produce will be the markets of northern Asia, South-East Asia and the Pacific countries. Smaller inroads will continue to be made into opportunities in niche markets in Europe and North America. We have an example of that in Gippsland at the present time where a large multinational company closed down an operation in East Gippsland. The farmers rallied and resurrected the company. It is now known as Vegro and it exports its products to France. The owners have gone from an impossible position two years ago to a very positive position today.

Increased volume of exports will be made in refrigerated ships with produce packed in modified atmosphere packaging. This will produce an alternative to air freight and increase the competitiveness of produce. I do not know how many people realise it, but ANL has played a major role in the development of this atmospheric packaging in order to get our products to these niche markets. Part of the plea I would make to those who now have the responsibility for ANL, looking at what needs to be maintained and what needs to be chopped off, is that they do not throw out the baby with the bathwater.

In any industry that is developing a niche market, with the potential to grow, there is always going to be that problem of in between—where you cannot charter a full ship. You need to do specific work in order to develop your industry. ANL has played a major role in that area and we should not lose that. It could be to the detriment of our industry if we cannot make that jump to the levels required to go out and charter full ships and not get caught in the middle. We need to always bear that in mind when people are talking about what they are going to do with ANL.

The gross value of production of the horticultural sector will need to increase to approximately $5 billion by the year 2000 in order to service increased domestic consumption and increased exports of fresh and processed horticultural products. Research and development will be critical in providing new varieties suited to our growing areas. Also required are more efficient growing practices and substantial reductions in chemical use through the adoption of integrated pest management techniques. The demand for new varieties and exotics is likely to increase as consumers become more affluent. Australia is in a position to exploit these opportunities by developing new varieties and identifying niche markets.

It is ironic that right now in the main parliamentary chamber we are debating the Plant Breeder's Rights Bill, which is another crucial piece of legislation which was introduced by this government and is now being amended. That bill will have an enormous impact on the horticultural industry. Further, the demand for convenience foods is likely to increase, thus providing Australian horticulture with the opportunity to add value to its products and take advantage of new markets.

Major issues have been identified. The Australian horticultural industry has been protected thus far by tariffs and quarantine regulations. It has also been supported by statutory marketing authorities and subsidised by government contributions to irrigation infrastructure. This assistance is progressively being removed, with the result that horticultural producers must now become internationally competitive in order to survive. These changes should be seen as challenges that will ultimately foster a stronger, more efficient export oriented horticultural industry.

The horticultural task force, which has been mentioned by others, was established by the Commonwealth government and chaired by Senator Sherry, and it identified six major issues specific to horticulture which represent impediments to the development of competitive horticultural industries. These impediments need to be overcome if Australia is to become a major exporter of horticultural products.

The six issues are: the need for a substantially improved export marketing effort, including continued efforts to improve access to key Asian markets; reform of the activities of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service; the need for increased research and development, in which this legislation will be of assistance; improved access to capital; the need for greater leadership in horticulture; and reduction in production and distribution costs. That is a tall order, but one that we can certainly achieve.

In general, it is important for the Australian horticultural industry to develop an export ethic and to benchmark itself against overseas industries. There is a need for consistent quality, greater value adding and more innovative presentation of fresh and processed products. There is also a need for an improved organisational structure for export marketing in order to promote activities such as charter shipping, controlled distribution of long lines of brand identified quality product, and coordinated marketing. Increased efforts are also required in overcoming barriers to international market access.

The Commonwealth, in this legislation, is matching industry funding for research and development through the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. The HRDC needs to develop a clear strategy and increased adoption and commercialisation of horticultural research findings. There is also a need for an increased commitment to funding research and development to overcome quarantine barriers and provide an expansion of market access for Australian products. Austrade is playing a crucial role in assisting industry with exports in a range of products.

Improved access to capital from the financial institutions is a key issue. It is required by the horticultural sector. The capital invested in land needs to be freed by the removal of restrictions on land transfer and through positive encouragement to more farm build-up. We have seen it occurring, but it must continue. There is a need for improved leadership in horticulture through the development of nationally representative peak industry bodies.

High material costs for Australian horticulture are an issue. The ability to compete on a cost basis in export industries is obviously a factor of major importance, while there is also a need for industry to continually seek lower import costs and increased production efficiency. The honourable member for Gwydir mentioned the increase in diesel costs. To hear him talk, you would think the farmers were paying increased levies on diesel. That is not the case. The producers in agriculture in this country do not pay the excise, and they get enormous assistance in that regard. They may have a cost burden from any increases in diesel prices if they are shipping their stuff by road to the exporters, but the importers also pay equal costs, so there is no real competitive advantage imposed by that policy position.

The horticultural industry is, I am pleased to say, analysing its current position in regard to each of the key issues: the future vision, the impediments to the achievement of the vision, and the most appropriate strategies required to address and overcome the impediments. All horticulturists need to look outwards and learn from those producers who are currently exporting successfully.

In my previous experience in the 1980s in this parliament, chairing the primary industry committee, I had a hands-on approach to many of those issues of restructuring that were going on at that stage. The industry that I can talk about with the greatest depth is the dairying industry, which is important in the Gippsland region. That was an industry that also needed to look outward, and one that also needed to develop a real export orientation and a production approach to its products; and it did so. There was a lot of opposition to those changes—in fact, there was some violent opposition.

I have recounted to the parliament before now the story of a large meeting I attended with John Kerin in my electorate. Some 1,500 farmers turned up, and they were not even a little bit happy about the proposals we were putting to the diary industry. At the time, they saw it as selling them out, but we stood our ground. I must admit that John Kerin's car got a fair hammering when he was trying to get out from the meeting, but we stood our ground and the dairy industry did restructure. Today it is miles ahead of the horticultural industry because of that.

The embarrassment of that was that we tried to do the same thing in the area represented by the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). The member for Barker (Mr McLachlan), then the leader of the NFF, was a person who could see what was required to be done, but I am afraid the National Party elements at the time were exploiting the situation for political purposes and did not put their constituents ahead of their own political aspirations. Instead of supporting the changes at the time, they violently opposed them, as some did in the dairy industry.

We did not get the support that was required, and neither did the honourable member for Barker, the present opposition spokesman on the environment; and here we are today, eight years further down the track, still talking about the same issues. I think it is time that the members of the opposition right across the board, and not just those who know these issues from their own electorates, started to realise that there are times when one leads from the front. One does not stand at the back and make lots of noises for the benefit of politicians, to the detriment of one's own constituents.

The horticultural industry does need to look outwards. It is moving—it is certainly moving—now. An example would be that in those days I was talking about we were still producing juices with costs of $40 versus $150. The product that we are trying to produce cannot compete, yet because of our location in the Southern Hemisphere versus the Northern Hemisphere we have the opportunity to supply the Californian market. We have oranges in the Californian off-season, but we have done very little about it and we need to get our act together in that regard. I am sure that if the industry does get into this mode and does get into this operation it can look forward to an enormous future.

I want to talk a little about the Asian situation. Asia is an enormous market. There are enormous prospects there. By the year 2000, for example, 220 million Asian consumers will be earning over $US10,000 a year. Even in developing countries such as Indonesia, from five to 10 per cent of the population will be in the middle to high income brackets and will have ample money to spend on high value foods. With a population of over 190 million in that country, that means a market of some 10 million to 20 million people, and it is growing at a rapid rate.

It is time to take our head out of the mallee sand and look to the future, to listen to those in the industry who really are moving in the right direction and are moving their industry on. In my opinion they are moving eight years later than they could have done, but I am very positive about the moves that this government is making now, with the recommendations of the Sherry task force. That task force put very strong recommendations to the government. The industry itself now has to come forward and put the positives forward. It has to do what the dairy industry did. If it delivers the message to its own constituency it will see that it has a great future. I strongly support the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to join other speakers on this Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill 1994. In standing to speak on it, I must declare something of a vested interest, having spent most of my life in the horticultural industry and still having a very small, but nonetheless real, involvement in it. As previous speakers have said, this bill allows an expansion to the present act that permits the collection of levies for horticulture.

PARA.TAB: These levies are collected on a dollar for dollar basis, so industry money is matched by the government, and that money can then be used for research and development in the industry; or, where it is appropriate, where the industry is aligned with the horticultural corporation, it can be used for promotion. There has been bipartisan support for these bills and for the changes that this particular bill allows to the collection of levies for horticultural purposes.

As previous speakers have also said, levies are already collected on horticultural products in a variety of ways. Some are collected on a per tonne basis. Clearly, it is impractical to collect levies, for example, where fruit is being used in a processing role and is measured and paid for on a tonnage basis; so the levy is consigned on a tonnage basis. Where it is marketed in a case or a carton, it may be on a per carton basis. Where it is marketed, as is particularly sensitive and perishable fruit, in a tray, then it may be on a tray basis.

The changes that we are currently considering—and, as a government and opposition, are supporting—are changes that are being requested by the nashi industry, because the nashi industry clearly seeks more flexibility than the present act gives it, if nashi growers are to have a nashi levy collected in an equitable way. This proposal is that, in the case of the nashi industry, it should be possible for a levy to be based on the number of, or the area of, nashi trees held under cultivation by a grower.

I note that another area of change being considered as part of the legislation, to accommodate the strawberry industry, was to allow for a levy to be placed on strawberry runners at the point of collection, so that growers could use that as a means of assessing their involvement in the industry and the appropriate level of levy contribution they should make. As the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) has said, we actually have an instance already where some nursery products collect a levy on the basis of the plastic pot. Now one may ask, `What has a plastic pot got to do with the plant?', but the plastic pot is unique to the nursery industry, and so the number of plastic pots collected proves to be an equitable way in which to measure a grower's involvement and production in a particular industry.

The legislation before the chamber simply allows the collection of a horticultural levy to be more flexibly based. In that sense, it has the support of not only the government and the opposition but also of the horticultural industries that have sought this sort of change.

The honourable member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) has already made the point, and in fact it has been agreed by other members in this Main Committee chamber, that the collection of a levy for horticultural products is important because the horticultural industry offers such a great deal of export potential. It is unique that we have an industry that is as competitive as the horticultural industry is, when it is in fact also characterised by the level of labour intensity that is involved with horticultural production.

In many ways, the viticultural industry—which is in itself labour intensive, with all of the mechanisation that is now part of the growing exercise—has been characterised by its capacity to be value adding and labour intensive. It has led the way in export development and given an opportunity for other horticultural products to say, `This is what we believe we ought to be doing.' As the honourable member for Gwydir said in his contribution to this debate, there is right now for horticulture a narrow window of opportunity to expand into export markets, and it is into those export markets that horticulture is endeavouring to hurry.

The opposition can claim some credit for the government's initiative in promoting a horticultural task force. I was one who, because of my distinct interest in horticulture, was anxious to persuade the opposition leader of the time to consider the introduction of an opposition horticultural task force; and the present honourable member for Mallee was conscious of that, because he was also contesting an election at the time.

It was as a result of that opposition initiative that, I notice, the government responded with a government horticultural task force specifically charged with addressing the difficulties that were being posed at that stage by the citrus industry and by other horticultural industries. As a result of that government task force, we had some recommendations—some good and some bad—for the vineyard industry, and a number of recommendations that quite explicitly applied to the citrus industry and to the areas represented by the honourable member for Mallee and me.

This point ought to be taken up in the comments that the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) made about the so-called Kerin dairy plan. It is significant to note that, in the area of GATT legislation, we had an instance where the opposition was supportive of the government in promoting something that was unpopular. I felt that the honourable member for McMillan could have been a shade more charitable. He was critical of some of the things that happened in the run-up to the dairy industry, but the majority of people in the opposition coalition recognised what the Kerin plan had to achieve, and they endeavoured to make it happen.

In the case of the GATT reforms that have been so important to this government, it would have been much easier for the honourable member for Mallee and me to have simply been blindly in opposition to those reforms. We would currently be lauded as heroes in our electorates. The reality is that the government has had from the opposition a great deal of support in the necessary GATT reforms that it has pursued. It has been commended for those reforms, and it ill behoves either the honourable member for McMillan or, for that matter, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to not acknowledge the degree to which the opposition has forgone electoral popularity in order to do what it believed was in the nation's—and by implication, in this case, the government's—long-term best interest.

Furthermore, no industry was as sensitive to the changes that the government proposed under GATT, or as bruised by them, as were the horticultural industries and, in the case of the honourable member for Mallee and me, the citrus industry. The citrus industry is still unconvinced of the advantages that GATT has offered it, but the simple reality is that for primary industry in Australia GATT has been a plus, and it can be a real plus for the citrus industry.

I acknowledge that the lowering of tariff barriers has made it more difficult for one of Australia's key horticultural industries, the citrus industry, to stay in production, particularly in the production of concentrated juice. But this Main Committee, the honourable member for McMillan and the government all need to be aware of the fact that the citrus industry has not neglected the opportunity for export promotion that the GATT negotiations have given us.

I can proudly claim—and the honourable member for Mallee can endorse this, since the Mildura producers in his area have been very much a part of this, along with my producers—that we are getting into the American market for oranges. This Main Committee and the House ought to be aware of the fact that, while we stand here, there are ships steaming to America—four of them, in fact, on the water—loaded with Riverland and Sunraysia navel oranges, heading into the heart of citrus production in the world: into the American and, principally, the New York market—into direct competition with Californian producers. That is happening right now.

If we had been having this debate two or three weeks ago, we would have been having it at the time when the first of those ships had arrived had been unpacked. The Americans and the American horticultural industry had changed the rules while those ships were on the water. The original agreement had been that the citrus—and we are now talking about whole fruit in cartons—could be unpacked, and that a mould tolerance of five per cent would be acceptable. After all, that is the norm around the world. That had been the agreement.

These citrus fruits were unpacked, and the Americans said, `We are now going to apply a mould tolerance of 0.5 per cent. Sorry: typo error. This is what we really meant.' The fact that that sort of proposal was in place instantly meant that my growers and those of the honourable member for Mallee were about to face a repacking charge—with all of those cartons rolled over rollers and repacked—of $2 million for those four vessels on the water.

The Americans backed down, thanks to the action of the government and of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins; and thanks, if I might immodestly say so, to the actions of the honourable member for Mallee and of the member for Wakefield, who both supported the government in this instance; and thanks to the citrus industry organisations and to Mr David Cain, who is the General Secretary of the Citrus Board of South Australia, and who flew to America.

This is a good indication of what GATT has allowed Australians to do for the first time. The Americans faced the grim reality that, if they stayed on the course they were on and changed the rules, we could do the same thing when they sought to bring Californian navels into Australia. While they might well have scorned that, they also had to face the other reality that when they sat around a table called GATT with all the other GATT signatories they would be seen no longer to have played the game. So they acquiesced and those exports are going ahead.

It is a bit unfair for the honourable member for McMillan not to acknowledge the active participation of the citrus industry in that export market right now. However, it is quite fair for him to comment that there is need for additional leadership, additional entrepreneurial skill and additional innovation in the citrus industry. The government can help cultivate that, not only with the passage of this legislation but also with putting in place some of those recommendations that its own Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Sherry, has put his name to in the government's horticultural task force report.

Much of what the horticultural task force proposed has been picked up appropriately by the member for Mallee. I endorse his comment that we would seek from the government some commitment to ensure that the planting tax write-off that the government introduced for viticulture, 12 months ago or less, also applies to horticulture. With real passion I say to the government members opposite that it ought to apply because otherwise wrong signals are being sent into the areas we represent. The signals going right now into the Riverland and Sunraysia are, `Let's plant grapes because there is a tax write-off for doing so.' That is currently to the disadvantage not only of the citrus industry but also of the stone fruit industry and the dried tree fruit industry. Frankly, I think we should be sending a signal that says, `Let's expand our potential horticultural export production by offering the same tax write-off for trees as we do for vines.'

It is dangerous for the government to nominate a success story, such as that of the wine industry, and to put too much emphasis on it. It is complicated by the fact that we are then saying to a dried fruit grower, `You ought to be putting in dried vine fruits because of the tax write-off and not dried tree fruits where there is not a tax write-off.' I believe that issue ought to be pursued.

The other issue that ought to be pursued diligently by the government—it has already been picked up by the honourable member for Mallee—is what we do about the current tax as it applies to citrus juice in Australia. The point has been made that, in the case of the dairy industry, whole milk can be produced in Australia under the present tax regime and no tax applies because fresh milk is regarded as a food product. As the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) would be aware because he has a number of dairies in his area, there are no dairymen who would suggest that we ought to be putting a tax on whole milk either. It ought to continue to be regarded as a whole food product. I ask the government—I have asked this question before and I ask it again now—what the difference is between squeezing juice out of an orange and squeezing milk out of an udder. In either instance a whole food product is being produced and the tax applying to it ought consistently to be zero.

The current arrangement that the citrus industry faces is that the government has generously agreed that wherever the citrus industry puts 25 per cent Australian product into its juice, as opposed to Brazilian concentrate or any other form, then that ought to get a tax differential so it is only taxed at 11 per cent instead of at 21 per cent. That distinctly has been an advantage to the Australian industry. Obviously, it is GATT illegal, because it is something that exclusively advantages the Australian industry to the disadvantage of any one of our competitors. If you take that away you put the Australian citrus juice industry at risk. The dairy industry has been debating over the last few weeks what it does with the way in which levies are applied to the dairy industry, and it has come up with a GATT-friendly way of solving its problem.

The opposition is saying to the government, `You ought urgently and seriously to consider what the citrus industry is saying.' The citrus industry has put to the government a proposal that says, `We can no longer accept a tax differential for 25 per cent Australian product because it is GATT unfriendly.'

Instead of that, let us have a situation where juice squeezed out of an orange, like juice squeezed out of an udder, is tax free, and all other juice is taxed at 21 per cent. There is nothing GATT unfriendly about that. Anyone who wants to bring fresh juice into Australia—that is, juice not made from concentrate—will bring it in here and have it tax exempt; but anyone who is producing any other product and bringing it in—juice from concentrate, for example—will recognise that it has a tax burden of 21 per cent. This is the proposal being put by the largest processor in Australia, Berrivale Orchards at Berri. It was originally a grower owned cooperative, but it has now been modified and that is not exclusively true. It is saying to the government, `Let us amend the tax so that we favour not Australian product, but fresh product—consistent with what you currently do for the diary industry—and put all other product at 21 per cent.'

I do not know why the government should be hesitating about this, but I am not in government so I am not about to pass instant judgment on that. My point is that a decision is urgent; because, as everyone will appreciate, all processors right now are saying to themselves that it is obvious the 25 per cent advantage is about to go, and maybe it will be replaced with nothing, so they are not about to buy any oranges as if there is going to be a continuing 25 per cent advantage on Australian product.

They are presuming that there will be no particular advantage in using Australian product; and as a result, as the member for Mallee has said, we currently have a situation where growers producing export whole fruit for the Californian market are getting a good price on the Californian market but are getting nothing for their juice overrun. They get nothing for their juice overrun because no-one wants to buy it, because people think they will be able to get it more cheaply because the present regime is not going to continue. That is a disaster. Why bother to grow oranges at all for a potential export market when half of them are going to disappear for nothing and when, as the member for Mallee has said, what you get for the juice will not only be less than the cost of production, but less than the cost of picking the fruit?

The proposal is simply this: growers recognise, reluctantly, that GATT may not have been to their disadvantage and that the government and the opposition may have been right in standing up as they did for the GATT changes; and they now recognise that GATT will mean that they can no longer continue with the advantageous situation they have had in the past. They are saying, `Let us change it. Let us accept that whole fruit fresh product is a food and should be tax exempt, and that all other processors ought to be taxed at 21 per cent. We are then putting to the government a proposal that will cost them nothing in revenue terms and will ensure that the export potential of the citrus industry can continue to be realised.'

Mr Deputy Chairman, I noticed that the honourable member for McMillan concluded by making a comment or two about what he saw as the inconsistency of the honourable member for Gwydir in referring to the diesel rebate. I only want to remind the member for McMillan that the member for Gwydir's reference was simply to the fact that all rural costs go up because of the greater dependence that rural people have on fuel. The member for Gwydir, as a farmer, knows that the on-cost of diesel is rebatable to him, but that does not alter the fact that his shearer—or anyone else working in any one of the towns he represents—has an additional cost for his motor vehicle every time the cost of fuel goes up.

The member for McMillan said in his concluding remarks that horticulture was moving. I quote: `Horticulture is moving—it is certainly moving—now'. He was, of course, right. It is almost September and there is not a horticultural crop that is not about to burst into bloom. In that sense, horticulture is certainly moving; and if in fact this legislation does what the government hopes, then this may well be the spring for horticulture in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Mr H.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be here in this less confrontational room. I had a certain objection to this room when it was first proposed, but having come here for the first time I think that perhaps the exchange of ideas and debate might be better here than it is downstairs. It strikes me that that may be possible. So for all my doubts, it might work in the end.

PARA.TAB: Let me commend the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) on his obvious knowledge of and concern for the horticultural industry in particular, but also generally for all agricultural industries. It is a concern that we all are very focused on at the present time with the dreadful drought that has beset much of Australia. I know that my colleague the honourable member for Calare (Mr Simmons) is also deeply concerned about the plight of many country people due to the drought.

I am here to support the Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill 1994, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1994 and the Horticultural Export Charge Amendment Bill 1994. I am pleased, because this presentation of this series of bills was prompted by sections of the horticultural industry. The purpose of the bills is to improve the flexibility of the collection of levies and charges on the horticultural industry and to improve their fairness and their equity. I think those three terms—flexibility, equity and fairness—reflect areas in which this government has a fine record and it is continuing to strive towards those aims.

The implementation of these bills will allow an expanding horticultural industry to broaden the basis for levy collection on horticultural products. It will allow individual sectors of the horticultural industry the right to impose levies appropriate to their needs. The three bills are drafted separately because of constitutional requirements to isolate legislation which involves charges from those which involve levies. The bills should, however, be considered together as part of this package.

The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay), in his second reading speech, indicated that the bills will amend the Horticultural Export Charge Act 1987 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 to enable levies to be collected on the basis of the area under cultivation or other horticultural inputs to the production process, such as the number of trees, shrubs, plants, bulbs or tubers which are under cultivation.

In order for the levy to be imposed in this way, it will be necessary for a presumed yield from those horticultural inputs to be specified in the regulations. It seems particularly correct to me that the horticultural industry has come to the government with these proposals. The government—and in particular the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Sherry—has been a vocal advocate of the industry attempts to restructure itself in order to take advantage of significant market opportunities, both domestically and internationally, that are around.

I have had some involvement in helping the leaders of the industry in that respect. I released the Horticultural Policy Council's report Winning the race: international competitiveness in Australian horticulture at the Qantas cargo centre at Mascot airport some months ago. That report reinforced much of the content and findings of the horticultural task force which was led by Senator Sherry. Both of the reports identified huge market opportunities for export, particularly in the Asian region, but sounded warnings that Australian producers and the rest of the community would miss out on the benefits of those opportunities if the industry failed to restructure and become aggressive and internationally competitive.

I remember being asked by a journalist after releasing that report, `Have we missed the bus?' and I said, `We have not missed the bus, but we are certainly not on the gravy train.' So there is a lot of work still to be done to become internationally competitive. The move towards international competitiveness, largely from the nashi fruit industry, and that is also likely to be followed by strawberry producers and others, signifies to me that the industry has heeded and is heeding the call and is starting to examine closely how it can reach its full potential.

Of course, that is only an initial, small step and the others that are likely to follow could be more difficult, but it is a positive start. I would like to assure the industry representatives that proposals to improve their international competitiveness will be considered very favourably by this government. I would expect that such moves would gain bipartisan support, as has this legislation.

If we look at the Horticultural Policy Council document, Winning the race, the massive potential for this industry is abundantly clear. It is estimated that horticultural exports have the potential to reach the value of $2 billion by the end of the decade. You cannot underestimate the impediments and the hurdles to be crossed in order to achieve that target, but the potential has been set and it is up to all those involved in the industry and in the government to do everything they can to ensure that that target is reached.

The myth of the 1950s, 1960s and 1970s that things in Australia would continue to improve without any real effort is dying—people no longer think that way. Effort, investment, dedication, leadership and knowledge are needed. The domestic market itself will become ever more subject to international competition and, even to survive here, industry needs to take on the rest of the world in both price and quality.

Horticulture is Australia's second largest agricultural sector, with a gross value of production in 1991-92 at $644 million. It is second only to the beef industry and, surprising to many, ahead of grains and wool. While the export performance of certain sectors of the industry has improved in recent years, exporters have faced increased competition, particularly from southern exporters, such as Chile, South Africa and New Zealand.

In 1992-93, fresh and processed horticultural exports comprised: fresh fruit, $208 million; fresh vegetables, $114 million; processed fruit, $140 million; processed vegetables, $25 million; nursery products, $27 million; dried grapes, $83 million; nuts, $20 million; and other, $27 million. The major commodities of the Australian horticultural industry are, of course, fruits, nuts, vegetables, nursery products, cut flowers and also cultivated turf. The majority of the fresh produce is exported to Singapore, Hong Kong and Malaysia, while processed fruit and dried fruit are destined predominantly for Europe, Canada and Japan.

Australia is self-sufficient in horticultural produce. Fruit and vegetables are mostly grown for sale as fresh produce on the domestic market or directed to processing. Some 80,000 growers are currently engaged in horticultural production, with a further 11,500 employed in fruit and vegetable processing. Australian shoppers spend $1.25 billion on fruit and vegetables in supermarkets a year.

So it is clear that the industry is a major contributor to the Australian economy and to employment. It is also clear that efficiency improvements will improve the industry's export performance and bring benefits to Australian consumers. The benefits of an efficient industry are clear. The entire government and opposition should applaud the efforts of the industry in bringing these proposals to government.

It is my view that the Australian horticultural industry has been focused on the domestic market for far too long and has taken very little interest in the world market. At the same time, the industries in other countries have been adapting and improving their international competitiveness at a faster rate than we have.

The clear message in the horticultural report, Winning the race, is that the Australian horticultural industry needs to address a number of issues in its quest to increase its competitiveness on world markets. We need to develop an export culture and coordinate our marketing activities in order to meet importers' demands for large quantities of consistent product. We need to bear in mind that our international competitors are characterised by large, vertically integrated companies and single-desk marketing authorities. We need to focus on the Asian region, where export prospects are greatest. We need to strive for consistent quality, greater value adding and innovative presentation of fresh and processed products. We need to look at our industry practices and benchmark them against our overseas competitors. We need to adopt more cost-effective methods, such as coordinating our export shipments with other Australian suppliers and making more use of charter services. We need to focus on the requirements of importers and develop high quality products and marketing strategies to meet those needs. We need to promote the advantage that Australian produce has over many of our competitors, capitalising on our clean and green image as a producer of wholesome food.

If Australian horticultural industries do not meet the challenge to make the changes and increase competitiveness, they will continue to lose market share, not just in export markets but also on the domestic market. In other words, it is the next few years which will show whether we miss the bus.

In all of this there is an obvious role for government, starting with the bills before us here this morning. In Winning the race the Horticultural Policy Council has set out a number of areas where domestic and international competitiveness can be improved through the activities of government. In section 3.11.1, on `Government Regulations and Charges: the Australian Perspective', it says:

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of government regulations and charges which impact on the development of horticultural exports and reduce our international competitiveness. The main charges are AQIS export inspection, levies payable to statutory marketing and R&D authorities, payroll taxes, workers compensation, superannuation, training guarantee levy, road transport, customs and port charges.

Many of these have been addressed or are in the process of being addressed by the government. Last year's budget announced significant changes to the operation of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, where the benefits will flow through to all exporters of Australian primary produce. The levies payable to statutory marketing and research and development authorities are being addressed to some extent here this morning. Payroll taxes, of course, are a matter for the state governments. The training guarantee levy has been abolished. We are also addressing the road transport charges by making our road and

rail networks more efficient and appropriate to the needs of industry and continually improving the efficiency of our ports. It could hardly be said that we are sitting on our hands or that we are not responsive to the needs of industry bodies.

PARA.TAB: The report says that competition should be introduced into export inspection by allowing appropriately experienced private companies to provide export inspection services. Though the terminology may vary, this is being done through quality assurance programs run and administered by the industries where they have an effect.

Quality assurance is an area to which the industry needs to devote significantly more attention, and I hope that the research and development initiatives which these bills will promote will help to achieve that end. Winning the race says that the Australian growers are primarily supply driven and on the whole are domestically oriented in their attitudes to production and product quality standards. In the past these attitudes have caused significant problems with horticultural export outcomes, with the result that Australian horticultural products generally have a less than satisfactory reputation for quality.

This is an area where it will be difficult to convince overseas buyers that there have been significant developments. Once a bad reputation has been gained it is difficult to shake, but improvement has been achieved in a variety of other industries and there is no reason why it cannot occur in horticulture generally. We need to convince our overseas buyers that there has been a massive attitudinal change in our horticultural industries and that this change of attitude has been reflected in the quality of the products that we make available for export. All groups in the Australian horticultural industry need to be convinced that it is worth doing and then they need to tackle it head-on.

To date there has been some resistance from certain sections of the industry to that sort of approach, and I hope that will change. The culture within the entire Australian community has changed over the past decade. There is a growing recognition in the Australian work force that quality is paramount, that the jobs of workers depend on it and that the profitability of Australian companies also depends on it. In horticulture the traditions of the farming community die hard, but the attitude towards quality is changing and accelerating. With enthusiasm and leadership from particularly the leaders of the industry, it will not be long before virtually all sectors of the industry are committed to quality assurance.

Though identified as cost factors affecting international competitiveness in the industry, quality research and development are important keys to success. Developing new products, researching market opportunities, providing those markets with products they want, not simply what is available, are important keys to unlocking the success of Australian horticulture.

Despite all the opposition scaremongering that we seem to get at budget time each year, the government's commitment to match industry research funds—dollar for dollar, up to the half a per cent of an industry's gross value of production—remains firm. This is an important initiative and one which industry leaders should pursue more actively. I hope, and I am reasonably confident, that the new structures for levies and charges that we are discussing here today will encourage those industry leaders to do just that. I am confident, too, that these measures will lead to a more equitable arrangement for the collection of levies and charges so that those who benefit from the development of new products and markets pay their fair share of the research dollars.

In the past, I believe many in the industry have been able to shirk their responsibilities but have reaped the benefits of the payments of others. That is clearly unfair and does need to be addressed. This package of legislation does not impose the solution of non-payers on industry leaders but offers them the choice of making some alternative arrangements so that they may force those people to cough up the dough. The bills will achieve much more than this but, even if they did not, this would be a worthwhile outcome.

Finally, my interest in this topic is due to the industry in my region and it is not merely academic. It has got a direct impact on the well-being of many of my constituents. On the New South Wales north coast there are 250 avocado growers, growing about $16 million worth of fruit from 1,000 hectares of property. There are 1,200 banana growers, producing 35 per cent of Australia's crop on family farms which cover about 5,200 acres. That is a crop worth $60 million a year. There are 60-odd blueberry growers growing 70 per cent of Australia's crop in an industry worth about $4 million a year.

There is a fledging coffee industry with the potential to produce millions of dollars of income each year. There are more than 100 flower growers in an industry worth $5 million annually. There are 90 kiwi fruit growers, producing over $2 million worth of crop on 150 hectares of vines. There are 500 macadamia nut growers producing about $16 million worth of crop on 4,500 hectares of trees. There are mango growers. There are registered nurseries producing an annual output of up to $140 million a year. There is $3 million worth of passionfruit produced from about 70 growers annually. There is $1.2 million worth of custard apples, $400,000 worth of grapes, $340,000 worth of guava, $400,000 worth of lychees, $6 million worth of stone fruit and $20 million worth of vegetables.

In total, for the north coast, there are about 3,500 growers producing about $300 million a year. We can see how important this industry is, even to one small region of Australia. It is at the crossroads. It needs strong leadership from the people in the industry and it needs encouragement, both from the opposition and the government, in putting in place the framework which it can work properly within. I think the next five years will tell the story of horticulture: whether it is able, as we have seen perhaps in the wine industry, through leadership and aggressive marketing, to break into those markets and to get as much a share or more of that $2 billion potential in Asia as possible. I commend this legislation to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to join in this debate because, like my colleague and friend the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods), it is the first opportunity that I have had to speak in this second chamber. When I walked in here this morning it was reminiscent of walking into a parliamentary committee that I am privileged to chair because I saw one of the opposition whips, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), and the honourable member for Page who are also part of that committee.
—There are six whips now.

—That is right; we do have plenty of whips. The atmosphere in here reminds me of a standing committee. One of the things that is often overlooked by people when looking at parliamentary processes and the making of legislation is the number of bills that have to go through both chambers—and now the Main Committee, of course—for which there is quite bipartisan support.

PARA.TAB: I have heard only a couple of speakers today. I caught the final comments of the honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) and I caught the speech of the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). His speeches dealing with agricultural issues are always well reasoned debates. We came into the parliament at the same time in 1983—a very auspicious occasion, as Mr Deputy Speaker would be well aware. All of the honourable member's speeches that I have listened to have been well argued. He has a considerable background in the agricultural area.

I am always fascinated to learn about the horticultural activities undertaken on the far north coast of New South Wales. I think there is a great danger, when we look at particular regions that our parliamentary colleagues represent, of making value judgments about the nature of the industry. If we asked an average person what the north coast of New South Wales is famous for, he or she would probably say the beaches and tourism, both of which are indeed very important.

The figures that have been mentioned by the honourable member for Page, in his very useful contribution this morning, give some indication of the enormous diversity of the region. He was talking about $300 million worth of export potential in the horticultural area. That brings me to the reason that I am participating in the debate. I represent an area in the central western part of New South Wales including the city of Orange, which coincidentally happens to be the largest apple growing district in Australia. The name of the community and the particular export that is associated with that region are for some people a source of amusement.

Horticulture has undergone a great deal of change. It has had great challenges and opportunities open to it in recent years. The honourable member for Page was absolutely right in saying that when we talk about horticulture, as with so many other agricultural industries in this country, it is very easy to think that the good times will roll as they did during the 1950s and 1960s.

However, we forget about the enormous changes that have occurred in the world. No longer are Australian farmers, or the Australian community, owed any special favours by the rest of the world. We are there to compete with major export countries and no-one owes Australia favours. We have to be there with very good products at very competitive prices. This debate has also been useful because of the wide ranging nature of some of the issues that have been canvassed. One of the advantages of a cognate debate such as this, where we are talking about a range of related bills, is that it gives people the opportunity to raise some of these particular concerns. Along with four other members of the powerful and influential Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I had the opportunity to participate in a visit to Taiwan.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Hollis)—Surely, led it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct, Mr Deputy Speaker. During that delegation, we had a number of discussions in which we expressed concern about the restrictive practices of the Taiwanese, particularly when it comes to apples. The honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who was the deputy leader on that delegation, certainly echoed the concerns that I had expressed and others in the industry had expressed about some of those restrictive practices.

PARA.TAB: In tabling our report in the parliament in the last session, we made mention of this particular concern. We noted that Taiwan, in parallel with the People's Republic of China, was seeking to accede to the General Agreement on Tariff and Trade, the GATT, and wanted also to be an original member of the World Trade Organisation. We have taken a position as a nation of supporting its application to join GATT provided, of course, that Taiwan brings its policies into conformity with the GATT rules. The particular issue that I mention—that is, the restriction placed on a range of agricultural items including apple exports to Taiwan—was discussed by members of the delegation with a number of ministers during our recent visit to Taiwan.

The attitude of the government there was that Taiwan was very much in the process of opening up its markets, but agriculture posed particular difficulties. During the course of their remarks, the ministers argued that they needed a transition period of up to five years, maybe six years, as it was impossible in their view to abolish existing quota systems overnight. The interesting point was that they said that farmers in Taiwan account for approximately 14 per cent of the population, yet agriculture now accounts for some three per cent of gross national product. They are, however, a very significant force and changes will certainly have to be made incrementally. We hope that those incremental changes will be at a much faster rate than the five- to six-year period that they have mentioned.

In that context, given some of the structural adjustment that Australian industries have been through in the last few years, what that does is to bring into some sort of focus the fact that we are not alone in having to face up to these particular difficulties of restructuring—not just in the economy in general, but in agriculture specifically—and the problems they bring to bear. While it is fair to say that the agricultural sector represents a significant political force in this country, the fact remains that that political force is represented by the largest country party in this parliament. The government party, the Australian Labor Party, represents some 27 of those important regional and rural electorates right throughout Australia.

In making my comments about the significance of apple growing within the Calare electorate, and with the comments made by the honourable member for Page (Mr Harry Woods) about the diversity of horticultural products on the north coast, honourable members can get some sort of indication, by the fact that people like ourselves have been returned to the parliament, that we have some knowledge about the importance of those industries, that we have relationships with the agricultural organisations, the individuals and the farming groups within our respective communities. We like to think, of course, that they would have confidence in our ability to represent them.

It is significant that horticultural exports represent an enormous opportunity for export growth. We have talked about figures of upwards of $2 million of exports towards the end of this century. In line with some of the recent reports, like other speakers, I join in commending Senator Nick Sherry, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, on his very valuable work in terms of the horticultural task force report. Those particular recommendations and those issues that have been raised there have been canvassed over wide ranging areas of Australia. I believe that the report enjoys very broad support from people right across the horticultural sector within this country.

Another aspect, not just in relation to horticultural exports, but in relation to foreign exchange earnings generally in this country, is the potential of Asian markets. We all talk rather blithely at times about the significance of the Asia-Pacific region as the fastest growing economic region in the globe at the present time. That is certainly going to continue, but I think we also have to recognise that we have very valuable opportunities in what we see as an emerging and a very significant force, number wise, in what we might broadly call the `middle classing' of many of those Asian nations.

Our important neighbour to the very north of Australia, Indonesia, has a middle-class population equivalent to the total population of Australia. That so-called middle class within Indonesia is expanding quite rapidly. Obviously there is potential in Indonesia in terms of agricultural exports, particularly for fresh food products, from Australia.

Further north of Indonesia, India—a country which I know you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would be well aware of—has a very significant middle class, in terms of the way in which we would judge that in Australia, with a potential of 80 million to 100 million people. Often we tend to overlook markets like that in terms of opportunity for exports of a range of products from Australia.

These particular bills pick up some of the ideas that have come forward from a range of people within the industry. Hopefully, these bills will allow the potential in horticultural industries to be unlocked, so that there is greater flexibility and opportunities to pursue their needs through their various marketing bodies.

Significantly, as a number of speakers have already commented on to date, there is very strong support for this legislation from a range of particular industries. The amendments that are being made today have been made at the request of the nashi fruit industry, which is proposing to alter its levy arrangements from a levy imposed at the first point of sale to an arrangement whereby levy is collected based on the number or area of nashi trees a grower has under cultivation. This will enable the levy to be collected from the grower based on the presumed level of production of nashi fruit, as stated within the legislation.

The strawberry industry is another industry that has been specifically cited by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) in his second reading speech. That industry is considering implementing a national levy for research and development payable by the strawberry grower at the point of purchase of strawberry runners, again based on the assumed production of strawberries.

We tend to blithely skim over some of these industries. We are obviously aware of the significance of the dried fruit industry, and the importance of the Riverland industries which the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) commented upon. We have heard about some of the niche market fruits that have become very popular in recent times, but it is often overlooked that important fruits, like nashi fruit and strawberries, offer similar potential, and that potential has been recognised by a range of people within the industry.

One of the great advantages of this country is its large size—covering an area of more than seven million square kilometres. It also has a great latitudinal range. Virtually anything can be grown in Australia. As Australia is strategically placed in the vicinity of the fastest growing part of the economic world, over the next few years we will be able to take full advantage of our location.

These particular amendments carry on the process that was begun by the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, John Kerin, in overhauling some of the statutory marketing authorities in the mid-1980s. As the member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) commented, reform had to be undertaken, despite some great controversy and very fierce protest in some industries. I am sure that many of those who were protesting at the time, thinking that their security, lifestyle, and the way in which they had been going about their farming business for years had been threatened by some of these changes, are now very grateful for John Kerin's initiative and leadership.

The same leadership has been shown by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, in responding to some of the needs of the industries that are coming forward within this legislation. His response is an indication that this government is well and truly in touch with the needs and aspirations of people in agriculture generally, and in the horticultural sector in particular.

I commend the three pieces of legislation that are part of this cognate debate in the Main Committee today. I know that they will be supported, but, more than that, they will be welcomed, by the industry at large.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was the case for my colleague before me, this is the first occasion I have had to raise a matter in the second chamber. I am pleased to do so and I am sure that I will be in attendance for many debates in the future.

PARA.TAB: I rise to support these three bills under the primary industries portfolio, the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1994, the Hortiultural Levy Amendment Bill 1994 and the Horticultural Export Charge Amendment Bill 1994. I believe that they have a major significance for the primary industry sector. The Horticultural Levy Amendment Bill 1994 enables a levy to be imposed on the leviable horticultural products or class of products that are presumed to be produced in Australia. The amendments would broaden the base of levy imposed to include presumed production. A new subsection would allow the basis of the levy imposition by imposing a levy on prescribed amounts of leviable horticulture products of a prescribed class that is presumed to be produced in Australia.

The reason for the amendment is that the existing basis of levy imposition has discouraged additional horticulture industries from becoming levy paying members of the Australian Horticultural Corporation and the Horticultural Research and Development Corporation. Section 7 of the Horticultural Levy Act 1987 refers to the rate of levy being the sum of the rates prescribed by virtue of sections 8, 9 and 10 up to a maximum of five per cent of the average of the gross values of production of the products. The rate would now be set by regulation. This section will operate only if the Australian statistician has published an annual gross value of production in relation to a class of horticultural products for the first three of the four immediately preceding financial years.

Clause 5 of the Bill allows for the making of regulations prescribing the way the amount of leviable horticultural products of a prescribed class, presumed to be produced in Australia, is to be determined. This can be done with reference to any one or more of the following: the area under cultivation; the number or quality of trees, shrubs, plants, bulbs, corms or tubers used or to be used; and the maturity of trees, shrubs or plants under cultivation for the above.

The second bill is the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1994, which has to be considered with the first bill. Levies and/or charges cannot be consolidated into one act because the laws imposing taxation can deal with only one subject of the taxation or duties of customs or duties of excise only.
The third bill is the Horticultural Export Charge Amendment Bill 1994. This bill is to assist producers who are exporting horticultural products to not pay a levy if they are already doing so.

The amendments proposed by these three bills would provide the flexibility required for a nashi, which is a sort of pear developed for the Asian market. That industry has requested a new levy to be collected on the basis of the number of nashi trees or areas of production.

The bills will also help the strawberry industry, as has been mentioned by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) in his second reading speech. That industry is also considering the issue of a national levy for research and development, a levy payable by the strawberry grower at the point of the purchase of the strawberry runners, which is based on a presumed production of strawberries.

We can see from these sorts of clauses that the industry is trying to come to grips with what its needs are and the best way it can collect levies to look at the R&D needs of the horticultural industries in the long term. These levies are compulsory, but they have been requested by the industry in order to ensure research and development does take place.

Before me, my colleague the member for Calare (Mr Simmons) mentioned the work done by Senator Sherry in his role as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Senator Sherry is a colleague of mine from Tasmania. His work was well done, and it certainly highlighted the need for more research and development to be done in the horticultural area. It found some big holes, and a need to pull together growers' organisations so that we can get a focus on that and so that government can know who to talk to in some of these areas.

This has had some excellent outcomes. The spending on horticultural research and development will increase by over $5 million this year, to almost $21.5 million.
